Award.AwardTitle: A Systematic Methodology for Data Validation and Verification for Prognostics Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks funding for the Center for Intelligent Maintenance Systems studies conducted by the University of Cincinnati site (lead), the Missouri University of Science and Technology site and the University of Michigan site. Funding Requests for Fundamental Research are authorized by an NSF approved solicitation, NSF 10-507. The solicitation invites I/UCRCs to submit proposals for support of industry-defined fundamental research.

The proposed research focuses on methods for controlling and evaluating the quality of data used in prognostic applications of system health and indicating when maintenance is needed. The proposal is well conceived, well organized, and the goals and objectives of the research are presented well. The tasks to be accomplished over the two years are clearly outlined, as well as which of the cooperating institutions will carry out the work.

The proposed research answers a significant research question raised by the industrial partners. For many companies assuring the quality of datasets before actually performing prognostics can avoid unnecessary investment in redundant prognostics analysis due to poor quality datasets. Assured data quality will improve prognostics results, which leads to better maintenance decisions and significant cost saving. The IMS Center has actively involved minority and female graduate students and has provided a number of Research Experience for Teachers and Undergraduates (RET and REU) projects.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has been conducted by the NSF I/UCRC center on Intelligent Maintenance Systems (IMS) including Missouri S&T site. The main application of the project outcomes is related to fault detection, root-cause analysis, and prediction to prevent costly unscheduled downtime and catastrophic failures.

Specifically, three types of outliers have been successfully studied and addressed through model-based approach:

  1. Random Gaussian noise in sensor input - including noise injected due to environmental factors, sensor quality and accuracy, and incorrect installation of sensors and wires.
  2. Sensor failure - including sensor damage, broken wire, and obstruction of sensor (e.g. due to clogging)
  3. Spurious errors and data corruption - including lost data due to system power disruption, corruption of data during transmission and storage.

These outliers result in false and missed alarms for the diagnostics and prognostics scheme. Missed alarms may lead to a costly, unscheduled downtime of machines, vehicles, and systems thus reducing competitive edge of companies. In the extreme, such missed alarms may lead to catastrophic failures with high repair/liability costs, injures and fatalities, for example, compressor explosion, nuclear reactor failure. On the other hand, the false alarms - while not directly harmful - have significant monetary and sociological impacts. The tangible costs include unnecessary downtime, and time and effort spent on diagnostics activities. Furthermore, due to repeated false alarms, the human operators will become distrustful of the alarms and may lead to disregarding an actual alarm thus leading to a failure.

Our research studies show that the developed model-based scheme is successful in detecting, labeling, and minimizing effect of the sensor data outliers on prognostics schemes. Specifically, the model based scheme takes into account the current operating regime, for example a pump's speed and load, to understand what are the expected, normal (or nominal) values measured by sensors. This knowledge allows the scheme to use very accurate detection thresholds. Consequently, the abnormal data are more accurately detected without compromising the failure detection accuracy.

The outcomes of the project have been shared with over 50 industry partners in the USA. The collaboration with National Instruments company on technology transfer is ongoing. A new model-based outliers tool is being developed for the Intelligent Maintenance Systems (IMS) toolbox. Also, the PIs submitted one article for publication in a professional journal - IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks. Moreover, the outcomes have been presented at two conferences: IAB 20 in November 2010 and IAB 21 in May 2011. Also, a third presentation is planned for IAB 24 in November 2012.

Students of the course EE-337 on Neural Networks for Control in Fall 2010 study the significance of data quality for real prognostic applications of the hydraulic pump and compressor system. The mutual benefits enriched the educational and professional development of these students and the teacher in terms of understanding the industrial context of the model and control theory based; and how to integrate the active learning with traditional curriculum.

Overall, the project supported four (4) graduate research assistants including one Ph.D. student and three M.S. students. Two of the students graduated during the project's course: Raja Kraleti, who has been subsequently employed at Caterpillar company, and Lathamaheswari Deepthi Raja, who has graduated in July 2012. Also, two (2) of the graduate students were women. The graduate students who are supported by this funding have been learning presentation skills. T...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project has been conducted by the NSF I/UCRC center on Intelligent Maintenance Systems (IMS) including Missouri S&T site. The main application of the project outcomes is related to fault detection, root-cause analysis, and prediction to prevent costly unscheduled downtime and catastrophic failures. Specifically, three types of outliers have been successfully studied and addressed through model-based approach: Random Gaussian noise in sensor input - including noise injected due to environmental factors, sensor quality and accuracy, and incorrect installation of sensors and wires. Sensor failure - including sensor damage, broken wire, and obstruction of sensor (e.g. due to clogging) Spurious errors and data corruption - including lost data due to system power disruption, corruption of data during transmission and storage. These outliers result in false and missed alarms for the diagnostics and prognostics scheme. Missed alarms may lead to a costly, unscheduled downtime of machines, vehicles, and systems thus reducing competitive edge of companies. In the extreme, such missed alarms may lead to catastrophic failures with high repair/liability costs, injures and fatalities, for example, compressor explosion, nuclear reactor failure. On the other hand, the false alarms - while not directly harmful - have significant monetary and sociological impacts. The tangible costs include unnecessary downtime, and time and effort spent on diagnostics activities. Furthermore, due to repeated false alarms, the human operators will become distrustful of the alarms and may lead to disregarding an actual alarm thus leading to a failure. Our research studies show that the developed model-based scheme is successful in detecting, labeling, and minimizing effect of the sensor data outliers on prognostics schemes. Specifically, the model based scheme takes into account the current operating regime, for example a pump's speed and load, to understand what are the expected, normal (or nominal) values measured by sensors. This knowledge allows the scheme to use very accurate detection thresholds. Consequently, the abnormal data are more accurately detected without compromising the failure detection accuracy. The outcomes of the project have been shared with over 50 industry partners in the USA. The collaboration with National Instruments company on technology transfer is ongoing. A new model-based outliers tool is being developed for the Intelligent Maintenance Systems (IMS) toolbox. Also, the PIs submitted one article for publication in a professional journal - IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks. Moreover, the outcomes have been presented at two conferences: IAB 20 in November 2010 and IAB 21 in May 2011. Also, a third presentation is planned for IAB 24 in November 2012. Students of the course EE-337 on Neural Networks for Control in Fall 2010 study the significance of data quality for real prognostic applications of the hydraulic pump and compressor system. The mutual benefits enriched the educational and professional development of these students and the teacher in terms of understanding the industrial context of the model and control theory based; and how to integrate the active learning with traditional curriculum. Overall, the project supported four (4) graduate research assistants including one Ph.D. student and three M.S. students. Two of the students graduated during the project's course: Raja Kraleti, who has been subsequently employed at Caterpillar company, and Lathamaheswari Deepthi Raja, who has graduated in July 2012. Also, two (2) of the graduate students were women. The graduate students who are supported by this funding have been learning presentation skills. They prepared presentations, industry reports, and professional publications. The knowledge generated from this work assists personal and intellectual development of researchers and prepare them for future careers in academia and industry. Last Mo...
